news politics tory-backs-smith-over-oscars-"Nadhim Zahawi reacts to Will Smith slapping Chris RockByLizzy BuchanDeputy Online Political Editor:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |comments A senior Tory has waded into the Oscars row and said hoped he would get up and lamp someonethey made a joke about his weaposs medical condition.Conservative MP Simon Hoare appeared to back Hollywood actor Will Smith, who hit Oscars host Chris Rock after taking offence at a joke about his we Jada Pinkett Smith. At Sundayaposs ceremony, Rock quipped, Jada, canapost wait for G.I. Jane , in reference to  film G.I Jane - which starred Demi Moore sporting a buzzcut similar to Pinkett Smith. Smith walked onto the stage and slapped the presenter, before ing to his seat and shouting: Keep my weaposs name out of your f****** mouth. Pinkett Smith has previously spoken about deciding to shave her head as she suffers from alopecia, which causes hair loss.  Smith, who later won the Best Actor award, used his acceptance speech to give a tearful apology to the Academy and all my fellow nominees - but not Rock. Mr Hoare, who chairs the Commons Northern Ireland Committee, tweeted: Re Will Smith incident @theoscarslive I’d just hopesomeone thought it in good taste to make a joke at the expense of a medical condition of my we then I’d get up and lamp him. The *joke* was tasteless.Education Secretary Nadhim Zahawi said Rock was mistaken to make the joke but violence is never the answer.He told LBC: Violence is never the answer to any problem-solving, as Will Smith admitted himself in that tearful, heart-wrenching apology. I think we should also remember - and Iaposm the Education Secretary - that actually sometimes even a joke can be below the belt. When a joke is about somebodyaposs we and her illness - she has alopecia - it is wrong. I think Chris Rock was mistaken to do that to Mrs Smith.  He added: I have to say, a first Oscar for one of my favourite actors was wonderful to see - marred by that incident, sadly. Asked how he would explain the incident to childrenhe was a teacher, he told BBC Breakfast: I would say, donapost do it. You could see Will Smith - and my heart was broken when I saw him, that tearful apology, he apologised immediately. It was hard for him because it was someone who made a joke about his we and her illness. Thataposs not easy but he regretted it and he apologised immediately. It is heart-breaking when you lose control of your emotions in that way, but I think it is important not to allow yourself to cross that line, and he apologised immediately, which is good to see. Labour leader Keir Starmer said he was pretty shocked by the incident. He told LBC: Anybody who insults family members excites something quite emotional in all of us. But on the other hand, to go up and hit someone in that way is wrong, Iaposm afraid. It was the wrong thing to do. Mr Starmer said he was struck by the fact that it didnapost appear to be completely spontaneous - saying Smith appeared to absorb the comments calmly and then reacted. Iaposm sorry, for me thataposs the wrong side of the line, he added.Smith wonapost face charges over the incident as Rock declined to file a police report.A spokesperson for Los Angeles Police said it is aware of an incident between two iniduals during the Academy Awards programme [which] involved one inidual slapping another. The inidual has declined to file a police report. If the party desires a police report at a later date, LAPD will be available to complete an investigative report. Smith won his first Academy Award for his portrayal of Richard Williams, the father of tennis stars Venus and Serena Williams, in King Richard. title: i catfished snap hunk now
story: I was catfished with a snap of a hunk - now Im dating the real guy in the photoNicole Hayden, a -year-old mum-of-two, thought she was chatting to a handsome man called Marcus, but his story soon unravelled. Then a few months later, she discovered something weird on InstagramNicole and Alessandro have been dating since January Image: Nicole HaydenByJessica TaylorReal Le Features Writer:,  Mar |commentsWhen Nicole Hayden first saw a photo of Alessandro Cinquini, she was instantly attracted to him.But as far as she was aware, the handsome hunk who had caught her attention after sending her a private message on Instagram was called Marcus.The mum-of-two from Palm Beach in Florida began regularly chatting to aposMarcusapos, who appeared to be a charming gentleman full of flattery, NY Post reports. But before long, the -year-old says her suitoraposs love pitch seemed to escalate and he suggested the pair get married and spend Thanksgiving together - just a few weeks after they first began chatting. She said: At that point I knew it was some sort of scam. We barely knew each other. I just blocked him. For more of the news you care about straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters hereThinking sheaposd escaped Marcusaposs clutches, Nicole went about her le as normal - but then he reappeared in a WhatsApp message after somehow getting hold of her phone number.This version of Marcus wasnapost as flattering as his previous form and began making nasty threats. When the pair had still been chatting on Instagram, Nicole had sent Marcus a photo of herself on the beach. Now, he was threatening to photoshop the image into a nude photo, which he would make publicshe didnapost send him money. Nicole claimed he even threatened to harm her childrenshe didnapost give over £,- but she stood firm and refused to comply with his demands.  Although she bravely stood her ground, Nicole was shaken by the incident - and when she saw a photo of Marcus a few months later, she felt startled. However, this time the photo was attached to an account by the name Alessandro Cinquini - who was the real person behind the handsome photo. Nicole said the fact Alessandro had a lot of followers and shared details about his le proved to her this was the real deal - so she decided to reach out to him. To her surprise, he only lived an hour away from her in Miami - and he was well aware scammers were using his photos to take advantage of women. Whereas at first he tried to take action against people using his identity, he has now given up trying. Nicole said: He has hundreds of fake profiles attached to his name. Itaposs crazy. After connecting online, the pair decided to meet in person in January - and they hit it off immediately. They are now officially dating. Nicole said she was wary of getting involved with Alessandro at first, given what happened the first time she got involved with the person she thought was him. But now she says her new love is amazing and sheaposs really excited to see what the future brings. However, there are issues with dating a man whose photo is used so frequently by scammers. Nicole said: He’s been out to dinner and had an angry woman come up to him. They complain that he ghosted them, maybe some of them actually paid money to a scammer because of his profile. It’s a danger for him in the real world.Do you have an experience with catfishing  Email jessica.taylor@reachplcRead MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Catfish" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: woman who went grey 11
story: Woman who went grey at  shows off brand new look after ditching hair dye for first timeEmiriana Litsa, , from north London, used to have her hair dyed every two weeks to cover her greys which first appeared before she was a teenager - but when she reached , she decided to embrace her natural locksEmiriana List used to colour her hair every two weeks Image: @silver_raven_emi News Dog MediaByPesala BandaraJessica TaylorReal Le Features Writer:,  Mar |commentsA woman who found her first grey hairs when she was just  years old is embracing her silver locks more than two decades on. Emiriana Litsa, from north London, says she used to dye her hair jet black every two weeks and let her true hair colour remain a well-kept secret. But after turning , she decided enough was enough and ditched the hair dye for good - making her final trip to the hair colourist in June , shortly before her wedding day. She said: I was about eleven-years-old when I got my first grey hair. I wasnapost aware of anyone my age with grey hair and I didnapost like how that early grey hair made me stand out. For more of the news you care about straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here When youaposre eleven, you just want to fit in and look like everyone . I began dyeing jet-black it at home by my teens and my grey hair became a well-kept secret. But she added that, by her mid-twenties when she had her roots dyed every fortnight, she was becoming exhausted and spending a lot of money. When I was in my late twenties, I started questioning beauty standards and the societal pressure I felt to hide my greys, she said. I would leave the gap between hair colour appointments longer and longer. I began to realise how much I loved my natural grey shade and how unique it was. As her grey hair began to grow out, Emi said she began to feel liberated and empowered by her decision, and learned to love her natural colour.  Four years on from her decision, she said: The only thing I regret is not making the decision to grow out my grey hair earlier.Emi now shares photos of her silver locks on Instagram @silver_raven_emi - and has also gone viral on TikTok after a video of her tresses was posted by the @worldmicrophone account.She said: I believe that women can and should set their own beauty standards. I think thereaposs something special about grey hair. Itaposs a part of me and thereaposs no reason to hide it. Women approach me and compliment me on my hair more now than before. Itaposs always very positive and many tell me that they love that Iaposve taken the decision to let my grey hair shine. I donapost want to ever tell any women what they should or should not do with their hair. But I hope I can prove that grey can be cool at any age! Itaposs my little contribution I guess.Do you have a real le story to share  Email jessica.taylor@reachplcRead MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON LoveViralHairstyles" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: army instructor chucked out military
story: Army instructor chucked out of military after slapping teenager on the bumFormer drill instructor Lance Corporal Oliver Nelson, , has been dismissed from the army over the incident in which he slapped an eighteen-year-old on the behindLance Corporal Oliver Nelson has been dismissed from the army Image: Jordan Pettitt Solent NewsByKit Roberts:,  Mar  An instructor in the historic Household Cavalry has been dismissed from the Army after he slapped the bottom of a young female trainee on a London Underground escalator. Lance Corporal Oliver Nelson, , struck the  year oldaposs buttocks with apossome forceapos and laughed out loud, leaving her feeling aposuncomfortable,apos a court martial heard. LCpl Nelson was a drill instructor with the  year old Household Cavalry Mounted Regiment, which is known for its iconic tunics and plumed helmets being at the heart of the Queenaposs birthday parade, royal weddings and state occasions. The regiment only began accepting women in  and Judge Jane England said unwanted, disrespectful behaviour like LCpl Nelsonaposs could discourage more young women from joining the Army.He claimed he was simply aposjoining inapos as some young recruits were slapping each otheraposs bottoms after a night out in central London.  LCpl Nelson also twice breached strict rules on the conduct of instructors by having alcoholic drinks with trainees - some of whom were under . At Bulford Military Court, Wilts, LCpl Nelson was dismissed from the Army. The court heard that on the way back to Hyde Park Barracks, which is just three quarters of a mile from Buckingham Palace, the teenager had been in front of LCpl Nelson on an escalator in Knightsbridge tube station. Prosecuting, Colonel Grant Davies said: The woman was ahead of Nelson and she felt a slap to her buttocks which she described was with some force. She turned around and saw LCpl Nelson laughing. The woman describes feeling really uncomfortable that he had done that at all. She felt so uncomfortable after the incident that when she found out LCpl Nelson was staying near to where she was, she felt she had to stay in a room with two other trainees.  Later on in the same evening, LCpl Nelson bought alcoholic drinks for the teenagers which goes against barracks rules on instructors socialising and drinking with the trainees. Colonel Davies added: They ed to barracks on the same evening. The woman and other trainees within the training ward were joined by LCpl Nelson who purchased alcohol to be consumed by trainees. LCpl Nelson was there and consumed alcohol in contravention of the standing orders.He again bought cider and spirits including vodka within a week or so of the first incident and took it to a trooperaposs room to drink with trainees, some of whom were under , the court heard. LCpl Nelson pleaded guilty to one count of carrying out conduct of an indecent kind and two of contravening standard orders. Dismissing LCpl Nelson from the Army, Judge Jane England said: [The female trainee] was supposed to be able to look up to you as someone she admired and respected, as someone who upheld the standards of her unit and the army as a whole. Instead, you acted in a completely disrespectful way towards her by slapping her bottom on a night out. She, as a woman, had the right to have a say in who does and does not touch her. Your regiment is one that has just opened up to females. It does mean perhaps you did not have experience dealing with females. But females should be encouraged into such roles. Subjecting young females to such unwanted behaviour is not consistent with that aim. Defending, Matthew Bolt described LCpl Nelsonaposs actions in smacking the young trainee as aposspectacularly foolishapos and added his client aposwanted to join inapos as other soldiers were slapping each other. Mr Bolt said: This was LCpl Nelsonaposs first time dealing with trainees and he became overly friendly as he wanted to be liked. This was a group of people who were friends. He interpreted the behaviour as banter, he wanted to join in but should have stepped back. He wanted to join in and it was spectacularly foolish of him to have done so. LCpl Nelson also received a two-year service community order and will have to do  hours of unpaid work in the next year. title: car bursts flames after driver
story: Car bursts into flames after driver crashes while live-streaming on TikTokA TikTok live-stream reportedly showed the moment a boy racer crashed his car on the A in Newham, London, moments after saying to viewers this is my playground, broThe car burst into flames on the A in Newham, LondonBySam OrmistonMatthew DreschNews Reporter:,  Mar A boy racer crashed his car live on TikTok moments after bragging about his aposrecklessapos driving. The driver can be heard saying aposthis is my playground, broapos as he weaves in between traffic on an East London A-road. But seconds later the camera jerks violently and the screen turns black, with the sound of screeching tyres and a loud bang ringing out.The car smashed into the central reservation on the A in Newham at shortly after midnight on Saturday, MyLondon reports. The vehicle reportedly shot up in flames and in a second video uploaded by an eye-witness, the passenger of a passing vehicle can be heard saying: Oh my god, itaposs a car on fire bro. Learn how to drive, did you feel the heat  In the TikTok live-stream, the driver was seen weaving in and out of other vehicles while travelling at what appeared to be dangerous speeds. The driver said this is my playground, bro while another TikTok star asked him how fast he was travelling, adding: Whataposs the speed on  Manaposs playing with death, you mad  Witnesses driving past could see at least three police cars and ambulances with a black car on fire, with flames reaching a few metres high, billowing into the air. One driver, Stephen Hill, commented: Pick just about any night on the A between Dagenham and Aspen Way and you’ll find cars weaving in and out of traffic, undertaking, overtaking, driving recklessly. Emergency services rushed to the scene including police officers, firefighters and paramedics and one man was treated for minor injuries at the scene.The video has so far gained more than , views when reposted on Twitter, with many users commenting on the driveraposs irresponsible and reckless behaviour.Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter A politan Police spokesperson told MyLondon : Officers were called at .am on Saturday, March , following reports a car had collided with the central reservation on the A just past the junction with Prince Regent Lane. Officers attended along with London Ambulance Service. London Fire Brigade also attended as the car was on fire following the collision. One man was treated for minor injuries. The driver will be summoned to court in due course. The London Fire Brigade and the London Ambulance Service have been contacted for further details surrounding the incident.Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON politan PoliceVehiclesPolice car" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: conman swindled two lovers out
story: Conman swindled two lovers out of thousands before they turned detective on himSara Muslin and Jane Fuller teamed up and reported Julio Sweeney to the police after he duped them out of a combined £, during the course of their relationshipsJulio Sweeney started relationships with single mums Sara Muslin and Jane Fuller around the same time Image: BNPSByCorey Ross:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsA charming conman who swindled his two lovers out of thousands of pounds was caught out when the women turned detective on him.Smooth-talking Julio Sweeney started relationships with single mums Sara Muslin and Jane Fuller around the same time and persuaded them to loan him money. Neither woman was aware he was dating the other until five months later when Miss Fuller became suspicious of Sweeney Facebook messaging aposwork colleagueapos Miss Muslin.She contacted care home manager Miss Muslin and the two began talking and realised they had both been conned. The pair, who were duped out of a combined £, by Sweeney, decided to report him to the police. Now firm friends, they sat in court as they watched as the aposheartless sociopathapos was sent to prison for  months after he pleaded guilty to  fraud offences.  The court heard that Sweeney, a carer, first met Miss Muslin, who is aged in her s, through work and they began a romantic relationship in March .Around the same time he also started dating Miss Fuller, an NHS worker aged in her late s who lived next door to him in Wimborne, Dorset.He asked Miss Muslin for a loan to buy a car and Miss Fuller, who he moved in with, for money to start up a business. Sweeney, , promised to pay them back but never did. He also took jewellery, which had belonged to Miss Fulleraposs late mother, and never ed it. Bournemouth Crown Court heard his actions had ruined the womenaposs lives. Miss Muslin said Sweeney took £, from her, which led to her going overdrawn and having to remortgage her house. Miss Fuller had more than  years service in the NHS, but the deception meant she had to be signed off work and struggled to cope when she did , getting several disciplinaries. She and her daughter also had to move house and she had to rely on her father to help her out with finances. Jonathan Underhill, prosecuting, said: Both were completely unaware that Mr Sweeney was in a relationship with either of them. In a remarkably short period of time he made a number of  representations in order to persuade them to give him money. He said they were short-term loans that he would repay and that he had the means to repay. The court heard that Sweeneyaposs deception came to light in September . Miss Fuller said: Although we never knew each other prior to this we did know of each other. I thought she was a work colleague and she knew I was a neighbour. He used to disappear for days, sometimes weeks at a time, allegedly aposworkingapos.On this particular day on hishis phone kept pinging when I glanced over to him Saraaposs Facebook profile bubble was on his phone.He said it was work and Sara wanted him to work a sht. I had a suspicion something wasnapost right and decided to friend request her. She said Sweeney was always charming and charismatic and had persuaded her and her father to loan him money. It was devastating to find out he was doing the exact same thing to another family. I was broken into a million pieces. He walked away with it all and left me with nothing.He probably stole in excess of £, in possessions and £, cash. He had two phones I had to carry on paying off. My credit rating is in tatters because of the debt Julio put me in. I defaulted on my phone and car payments. He is a heartless, selfish, manipulating sociopath who preys on single, hard-working parents to break them down and gets a kick out of doing so. Miss Muslin said her parents and children had both been taken in by Sweeney and she struggled to trust anyone now. She said: I was made to feel like I was going mad. He made me question myself and I was made to feel stupid. He took £, from me, I had charges for being overdrawn, high interest on credit cards, I had to remortgage my house and got a CCJ because of it. I had never been in debt before I met Julio. If he hadnapost taken my money I would not be in debt now. When interviewed, Sweeney claimed to police his relationship with Miss Muslin was sexual and she had put the money in his account so they could have a aposgood timeapos at hotels, festivals and on nights out. He said when the relationship ended she sent him a message saying she didnapost want any money back. He eventually admitted fraud against Miss Muslin of £, and £, against Miss Fuller. Edward Warren, defending, said Sweeny, originally from Trinidad, was of previous good character and had aposhis own vulnerabilitiesapos. In jailing him Recorder James Newton-Price QC said: Both of these women were unaware of the other. You cheated each of them by asking for loans which they could not really afford to give you. Both these women blame themselves but they should not. It was all your fault. I take the view that your conduct towards both women was manipulative and had a devastating effect. Sara Muslin you made her feel extremely foolish and put her into serious debt. Jane Fuller had to be signed off work on the verge of a nervous breakdown. You lack genuine remorse and victim awareness. title: dad 33 told 6 months
story: Dad, , told he has  months to live after waking up to find paramedics in bedroomFormer Merseyside detective sergeant Dave Bolton, from Greasby, Wirral, had a nocturnal seizure before being diagnosed with a Gliblastoma Multorme and given months to live. brain tumour aged " content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _Dave-Bolton-JPG.jpg" width"" "" Dave Bolton was diagnosed with a Glioblastoma Multorme . brain tumour aged  Image: Dave BoltonByCharlotte HadfieldRyan MerrieldReporter:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |comments A detective sergeant was given six months to live after waking up to find paramedics in his bedroom.Dad Dave Bolton was rushed to hospital following a horrying -minute nocturnal seizure before being diagnosed with a brain tumour. The then--year-old, from Greasby, Wirral, went to bed ready for his daughteraposs birthday the next day only to wake up with no idea what had happened.He remembers wolfing down a bowl of cereal prior to calling it a night only to find paramedics standing over him at around .pm, reports the Liverpool Echo. Dave had stopped breathing in his sleep. When he came round he felt groggy and was so surprised he tried to boot the medics out of his house. He recalls struggling to remember where he worked or his date of birth, when they asked him. The dad-of-two underwent surgery to remove the tennis ball-sized tumour at the Walton Centre and had to take medical retirement from his job at Merseyside Police.The following year, scans showed the tumour had ed and had become a Gliblastoma Multorme . A GMB is a fast-growing and aggressive tumour with a devastatingly short survival rate of just - months. Dave was told his diagnosis was terminal and he had six to eight months left to live with treatment or three months without. The -year-old said: I went away with a hard decision to make and slipped into one of the darkest places Iaposve ever been to. I spent about a week, two weeks, just lying on the couch.  I accepted that I was going to die and I just lay there and waited for it to happen. I just didnapost care anymore. The former world kickboxing champion, said it was his we Samantha who helped him to get out of that dark place in July  and he decided to tackle his brain tumour like a fight. He said: I just thoughtthe average is - months there must be people that go before then and there must be people who get up to  months. I thought youaposve never been average at anything, so what I did is, I kind of treated it asit was a fight. I named it Terry my opponent, and when I took on a fight say it was - months Iaposd go into a full on camp lockdown. I decided to tackle it  degrees, so by diet, exercise, forming good habits of sleep, alternative therapies, supplementation, mindfulness, mediation and then accept the treatments as well, so the gold standard. It was dual radiotherapy and chemotherapy followed by full on chemotherapy. Dave continues to outlive his terminal diagnosis over seven years later and in January this year doctors told him only small signs of the disease were visible.  He has now become a motivational speaker who helps people, charities and businesses and now runs a charity called Ahead of the Game Foundation, based in Wallasey, with former Premier League footballer Dominic Matteo.He has shared his story to mark Brain Tumour Awareness Month and highlight the need for more funding for brain tumours, with historically just one per cent of the national spend on cancer research being allocated to brain tumours. Dave said: Iaposm trying to use my own horric situations to remind people that there is another way, there is another option and there is hope. I’ll never be cured. I have to live everyday knowing it could come back at any second because even though I have. While the last scan showed there was no real evidence of the disease but there are still a web of cells, creating a perfect storm for it to spark but he has decompartmentalised it, he added.If you would like to donate to Ahead of the Game Foundation click here. title: familys search three mystery women
story: Familys search for three mystery women after matron leaves them money in willLaura Bisset was the matron at the St Christophers Railway Service Orphanage in Derby for  years and left something in her will for almost  people she cared forLaura Bisset was known as Miss Bisset during her time at St Christopers Railway Service Orphanage Image: Philip LoughByKelly-Ann MillsNews ReporterCallum Parke:,  Mar |commentsThe search is on to track down three women who will be in for a cash windfall after an elderly woman left them money in her will. Laura Bisset was the matron at the St Christopheraposs Railway Service Orphanage, also known as St Christopheraposs Railway Home, from  to  and in that time cared for thousands of children in Derby. After retiring to Wiltshire, the matron, who was known as Miss Bisset by those who were in her care, died aged  in December . In her will she left money to  charities and small bequests to several people, including almost  people who were once in her care.The executors of her will, her nephews Philip and David Lough, have tracked down all bar three of those who have been left money, Derbyshire Live reports.But the family need help finding the final three after the trail has gone cold. Philip Lough said: My aunt Laurie was a deeply philanthropic lady who devoted her le to looking after others.  We have had dozens of very moving letters and messages from former St Christopher’s girls, many still in the Derby area, who knew and loved her. So many have told us what a great influence she had been on their lives.We have used ious ways of locating them, including the excellent St Christopher’s Facebook page.We are now appealing to anyone who might know the current whereabouts of these three former St Christopher’s girls to contact us. Their names are Corina Jaffe, Sally-Ann Knight and Sheila Taylor. Corina’s last known address was in St Albans Road, Derby and Sally-Ann’s in Allenton, while Sheila is believed to have moved to Lincoln some years ago. The trail on all three has gone cold since then. The orphanage stood on the land that is now used as sports pitches at Markeaton Park, next to Ashbourne Road in the city. It was founded in  by members of the Railway Servantsapos Society after children were often left orphaned when their parents died in the course of their work, with Derby chosen as its location due to its strong connection with the railways at the time. The home originally had just  children, but after some adaptations, by the late s the new site cared for more than  children from all over the UK and Ireland. It was renamed St Christopheraposs Railway Home in , just before Miss Bisset joined as matron. Demand for places declined through the s and s and the main building was demolished in , to be replaced by two smaller houses. One of these became a home for the elderly in , before the whole site closed in . title: i spent 190 michelin star
story: I spent £ in Michelin star restaurant - it was weird and Pot Noodle has more flavourLucy Marshall visited Yorkshires only Michelin star restaurant, Michael OHares The Man Behind the Curtain in Leeds City Centre, which usually gets rave reviews for its expensive grubReporter Lucy Marshall spent £ in a a Michelin star restaurant in Leeds city centre to judgefine dining was worth the high price tags Image: Lucy Marshall LeedsLiveByLucy MarshallRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Mar |comments Despite the eye-watering prices Michelin-star restaurant The Man Behind the Curtain is proving to be a hit with fans of fine dining. Michael OaposHareaposs Leeds city centre restaurant gets rave reviews and Yorkshire Live Reporter Lucy Marshall decided to try it out. She says she is a self-confessed fine dining admirer with a aposwide palateapos and she was therefore keen to see what all the fuss was about.Lucy said she has been to some very fancy restaurants in her time and is a big fan of a tasting menu so she can try out new flavours and be a bit more adventurous with her cuisine. She therefore thought The Man Behind the Curtain would be right up her street. She was full of excitement and ready to e in. Sheaposd only had a porridge and cups of coffee that morning so at .pm on Friday, she was ready to feast. She walked inside to a grand marble staircase and it immediately felt luxurious. This is how her experience went. When Lucy walked in, she immediately felt at home and thought this is a bit of me. This was clearly a place of luxury and the surroundings made her feel like she was a rich woman about to enjoy the most opulent fine dining experience.Do you agree  Have your say in the comment section Front of house were very attentive and directed Lucy to a seating area which consisted of fur throws and white sofas. She was then able to peruse the cocktail menu - something that was again right up my street. The atmosphere was calm and edgy in her words and, although she enjoyed looking at the cocktails, the prices were extravagant with the cheapest £ for a single sip. She opted for a Cosmopolitan and was taken to her table. aposI wouldn’t call that Masterchef qualityapos Lucy says she was treated like a princess during her meal. Staff looked after her, even when she politely had to turn down having something from the wine menu due to the expensive prices. As she waited for food, Lucy discovered her first snag. She expected to be given some complimentary bread and butter while she waited as the hunger kicked in. Unfortunately she was given nothing until her first course arrived with the waiter serving her a fake white egg with a black star on it. There was no explanation from staff about the ingredients of the meal so she had to tuck in by breaking the egg and finding out was inside herself.  Inside, she found a tuna tartar with a spicy sauce. It was nice and fine but didnapost overwhelm her and she was still hungry meaning the next course couldnapost come soon enough. Next to arrive was a prawn on top of an old fashioned phone. Cool, extravagant and unusual but Lucy did also wonder why it had been presented like that as she said: I wouldn’t call that MasterChef quality. A big fan of prawns, Lucy bit into them after opening the shell. Normally she is a fan of seafood but said this literally tasted like it had just swam out of the ocean and onto my plate.  It said it came with tikka, but Lucy couldnapost taste any and wasnapost impressed at having to eat the prawns with her bare hands. After that dish, a bowl of soup arrived. But, it wasnapost quite what she was expecting as she was served this cold cheese thing with ice on top. Her hunger had not waned and scallops soon arrived, which Lucy admitted is one of my favourites. It was dressed in a really nice sauce but it wasnapost as exquisite as sheaposd hoped and she was still starving. Cod in squid ink followed and she soon realised there really was a preference towards fish in the restaurant. It peeled of her fork amazingly and was beautully cooked. However, an unappetising pork dish followed.  Describing it, Lucy said: Is it just me that thinks eating food that looks like a bonfire isn’t appealing  I don’t want to eat black food that looks burnt. We want colourful vibrant food that draws me in not scares me away. It was very nice to eat but the presentation left a lot to be desired for Lucy. She was then told she would be moving onto desserts - something which surprised her given the low quantity of food she was given for her mains. A mini tiramisu was served up first before a dark chocolate. She says these took a while to arrive, leaving her agitated and the saving grace was four macaroons that came in a iety of dferent flavours. aposA Pot Noodle has more flavourapos After her experience, Lucy had some concerns. Although she thought the restaurant was quirky and unique, she just didnapost get it. She said: While the place looked beautul it was just really weird. Even the kne and forks were abnormally small. If Iaposm paying £ for a meal I want proper cleaned expensive looking silverware. As much as the interior was sexy looking and fun, and the crockery and glasses used were beautul, the most important part of a restaurant is the food and frankly I left super hungry, unhappy and unimpressed by the food. Half of the dishes I could have made in my kitchen, and I think a Pot Noodle has more flavour than some of the dishes placed in front of me. I would tell people to go for a one-off experience, but I would not recommend it for a good and delicious meal. title: jobcentre new jobs vacancies government
story: Gov to get , people new jobs by June - find outyou fit the criteriaThe UK Government’s Way to Work plan is getting job-ready candidates into new roles – and supporting employers in finding the right staffWork Coaches at Jobcentre Plus are already helping thousands of employers connect with the people they needAdvertorialByDave MastersDigital Commercial Editor:,  Mar Looking to find a new job or fill a vacancy  Through Way to Work, Jobcentre Plus is offering employers a recruitment service that can quickly provide candidates who are the perfect fit.Jobcentre Plus has everything you need to move quickly. Right now, there are . million jobs available in sectors such as warehousing, logistics and manufacturing – so there are plenty of opportunities out there.For employers, Jobcentre Plus has thousands of quality candidates, ready to fill your vacancies quickly. The pandemic has been tough on everyone and highly skilled people have found themselves unemployed for the first time.Many may be considering a career change. These people can make a real dference to your business. And the UK Government is working with employers to get , job-ready candidates into work by the end of June. Many well-known companies already trust Jobcentre Plus with their recruitment needs – and you can too. To find out more, visit gov.uk waytowork. Eligibility criteria apply.aposWe had loads of jobs but not enough people to fill themapos  Screenprinting business Paul Bristow Associates is just one of the employers who’ve worked with Jobcentre Plus to fill vacancies. The family-run firm, based in Wrexham, produces textiles including T-shirts and printed bags – and they’ve been keen to attract younger people to roles. “One of the issues we have is the perception of manufacturing as being something we used to do in the Victorian age but no longer,” says director Ben Bristow. “Of course that’s not the case – but it made it hard to attract young people. Working with Jobcentre Plus gave us the ability to get more young people into the business and provide them with a good grounding in print and textiles.  “Our staff collaborated really well with the team at Jobcentre Plus, who gave excellent support and deserve high praise indeed.” HR manager Lee Dixon, , agrees: “The people who work there have done a fantastic job. It’s not been easy through Covid and the fact they’ve managed to help people into work is great. “It’s also massively helpful to us as an employer, given there are loads of jobs but not enough people to fill them. Through working with the team at Jobcentre Plus we’ve built up a great rapport. They’ve been first-class. “Our recruits have been a massive help in bringing in valuable skills to our business,” says Lee. “We’ve had them working in packing, admin, sewing and sales. Another guy has got a position in sustainability after he joined us from university. We’ve also had people with additional learning needs and disabilities.”aposMy team made me feel very welcome and supported meapos  “When I left college in January  I didn’t finish my A levels because I wanted a change, but then obviously the pandemic happened. I didn’t particularly know what I wanted to do, but I knew I would be good in a computer-based job because it’s something that I’ve gravitated towards. “Then I saw JD Sports was advertising opportunities and I thought I’d go for it because it was an administration role in a big company. It was actually the first that I applied for and everything went through really quickly – and I got the job. “My team at JD were great from day one. They made me feel very welcome and supported me. Day to day I’d look after anything from HR queries and issuing contracts to payroll and pension questions. It gave me pretty much a whole picture of what it’s like to work in HR and I’ve been doing it ever since. “I’d always had an interest in HR, but after working for six months I realised it was what I wanted to do. “There was the option to stay on and I’m now doing an apprenticeship with JD and CIPD Level  in HR support. It was another perfect step for me and I’ve now been there for a year and I’m really enjoying it. Starting work was quite tough, but I’ve got so much support from my team. It’s a lot more friendly than I expected it to be.“Now I’m learning about dferent parts of HR, building on what I was doing before. I was struggling to find any job with noexperience, but now I’ll just keep going.” Peter Cowgill, executive chairman of JD Sports, on how the company has forged links with Jobcentre Plus. “We are proud to have worked with Jobcentre Plus to provide much-needed employment and learning and development opportunities at a time when competition for job positions has been at an all-time high. Social inequality has only been exacerbated during the pandemic, so it has never been more vital to give young people a chance to succeed. “Our relationship with the DWP now covers all three nations across the UK and gives our stores, head office and distribution centres access to new talent pipelines and initiatives, which not only facilitates our future recruitment needs, but also allows us to support candidates facing social barriers, an area we are hugely passionate about.” “When I was developing my start-up in the renewable energy sector, working with Jobcentre Plus allowed me to recruit new graduates. “We’re part of the Edinburgh Business School incubator, where we get office space, mentoring and support. Since the graduates joined, we’ve moved to the stage of building a prototype.“If it wasn’t for the scheme, recruitment would have been years away –and having a few more minds to work on the concept has given us a competitive edge.“The candidates knew when they joined that they wouldn’t just be working on their own tasks and would be learning something every single day. If you’re looking for experience, it’s a great way to get it.” aposIt’s important to personalise our serviceapos  “Our service helps employers and our customers meet each other face to face, which is crucial. Employer advisers speak to both employers and the Work Coaches, who’ll send customers over who are ready for work. “We can also help employers st through CVs and hold training events to get people work-ready and match them up with the role they’ve got available. “I’ve been working closely with Lee at Paul Bristow Associates, who came along to events at the jobcentre where groups of young people could come and speak to him about what roles they had available. “A lot of employers weren’t aware of all the great services we offer, but the feedback we’ve been getting has all been really positive. Every employer’s needs are slightly dferent, so personalising our service is really important. “There are lots of sectors that are struggling to fill places, so we can help companies find a pool of candidates. We have large manufacturing areas in North Wales that are struggling to recruit people. There are also plenty of roles in the hospitality and care sectors.”Follow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON Department for Work and PensionsJD SportsLee DixonJobs CentreMost ReadRecommended

news uk-news mum-blasts-doctors-who-repeatedly-"Mum shares videos of her baby Esmai Wright suffering from seizureBySamantha Mordi:,  Mar |comments A mum has slammed medics claiming they repeatedly missed her daughteraposs brain tumour despite her filming horric seizures the infant suffered.Baby Esmai Wright is now battling   odds of survival after she was sent home from hospital several times.Mum Chloe Wright, , from Stoke-on-Trent, said she was given a dferent diagnosis every time they went to AE. But they were just sent on their way and told to wait for a referral letter. Bartender Chloe said doctors assured her that Esmai was perfectly healthy even though she was vacant behind her eyes. The tot was finally diagnosed with a rare and aggressive anaplastic ependymoma tumour the size of a grapefruit.  Shocking videos show baby Esmai suffering a seizure just hours after doctors dismissed her mum’s fears that she was unwell. Chloe filmed her baby going into spasm in a desperate bid to show doctors Esmai was seriously unwell. The first video was taken in Stoke Hospital on October  last year and shows the little girl appearing to go into a trance with her eyes wide open. Mum Chloe holds onto her daughteraposs hand until the seizure passes. Despite showing medics the videos, Chloe was repeatedly told Esmai was “perfectly healthy”.The next day, Esmai was filmed at home suffering a similar episode which was caused by an undiagnosed brain tumour. She was finally diagnosed with a large brain tumour and is currently undergoing chemotherapy. A CT scan revealed Esmai had a tumour the size of a grapefruit which had caused her entire brain to be pushed over to the left side of her head. She has been undergoing gruelling chemotherapy which has left her with painful ulcers and burns in her mouth which Chloe treats with ice cream on her dummy.  Chloe, of Stoke-on-Trent, said she first knew something was wrong when her little girl began staring into space in October last year. She was referred to a walk-in-centre by her local GP and Esmai was diagnosed with rigors – often known as absent seizures. The two of them were sent home but later that day Esmai suffered further seizures and an ambulance rushed them both to Royal Stoke Hospital. Chloe said: “We went through a cycle of Esmai having seizures which I would film and show to the healthcare team when we went to hospital.  Every time we saw a doctor, we had a dferent diagnosis and each time, we were told that she was perfectly healthy and to wait for the referral letter.” “I am obviously really angry that it took this long to diagnose my little girl. It is not common at her age to have seizures. One doctor went to speak to a practitioner without even seeing Esmai and said they didnapost think it was seizures. I was really mad. “They could have gone down a dferent routethey had picked it up earlier. I had to fight because I knew something was not right. “I knew my baby wasnapost well and I asked the doctorhe could do something, but he said there was nothing wrong with her. “I was angry nobody was listening to me.“My daughter is on chemotherapy now – every two weeks for a year – we have our good and bad days, but I do think this could have been avoided. The doctors said she would need at least a year of chemotherapy treatment and that the tumour is le-threatening with a survival rate of  per cent.” Esmai will continue chemotherapy until November and further treatment options of radiotherapy is available should the tumour grow.Chief Nurse Ann-Marie Riley, from University Hospitals of North Midlands NHS Trust, said: “We understand it is an extremely distressing experience for any parent when their child is unwell and we are very sorry that Ms Wright has had cause to complain about the service she and her child received here at UHNM.“It is our aim to deliver the highest standards of care possible and we are in contact with Ms Wright so we can fully investigate her concerns and resolve any issues.” Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON NHSBabiesHospitalsBrain Tumours" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: mum three family home used
story: Mum-of-three let family home be used as drugs gang torture chamber for kidnapped manJenner Baker, , was jailed after Kane Aitchison, , was abducted and held hostage in her property in Manchester for  hours in November Jenner Baker has been jailed for  months Image: Jenner Baker  Cavendish PressLtdByJon HarrisAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Mar |comments A mum-of-three allowed her family home to be used as a torture chamber for a gang after they kidnapped a man. Jenner Baker, , was jailed after Kane Aitchison, , was abducted and held hostage in her property in Manchester for  hours. Kane was beaten and stripped by eight men before boiling hot water was poured over his torso and genitals, Manchester Crown Court heard.He was told he would only be released once a £, ransom had been paid but when he said he had no money he was tied to a chair and had his hands and feet bound with a jumper wrapped around his neck. The kidnappers threatened to inject the victim with heroin in a bid to aposaposturn him into a junkieaposapos before they force-fed him tablets he believed to be rat poison.They also put him in fear of being raped before locking him inside a wardrobe. Kane escaped the next morning after biting through his bindings and sneaking past a sleeping guard who was armed with a hammer. He fled the property and was later treated in hospital for burns. Police investigating the attack found Baker had allowed the property to be used infor drugs.As the victim was being tortured she was heard asking the gangthey had any narcotics to give her. At Manchester Crown Court she admitted assisting an offender and was jailed for  months. Kane was bundled into a car outside his home by two men in November  and taken to Bakeraposs house against his will. Alaric Bassano, prosecuting, said: aposaposAt this house, he was imprisoned and assaulted over a number of hours. Demands were made that unless he handed over a six-figure quantity of cash, he would be gravely injurednot killed.  aposaposHe was assaulted in the kitchen and living room. He was punched in the face, dragged around rooms downstairs, kicked, stamped on, struck with a chair and had his head struck against a wall. aposaposHe was tied to a chair in the kitchen, his hands were bound with the cord from a set of hair clippers, his feet were bound with rope and a jumper wrapped around his neck whilst his face was covered with a sheet. He continued: aposWhen Mr Aitchison did not relent, the boiling water was poured over his torso and his genitals. A sock was inserted in his mouth and fixed in place with Sellotape which caused him to struggle for his breath. He feared he was going to suffocate.  The victim was taken upstairs, tied up and locked in a wardrobe. The following morning, after  hours of imprisonment, he bit through his bindings, forced open the wardrobe door and tried to escape through the bedroom window. When that failed he ran out of the house, avoiding a hammer-wielding gaoler and sought help from passers-by. He suffered signicant injuries, including burns.aposapos Mr Bassano added: aposaposaposWhether or not Baker was herself an offender, she was being recruited or used in a way which exploited her own addiction to drugs. She was the occupant of the premises and was present whilst the underlying offence was being committed and the use of her premises was vital to the commission of that offence. aposaposBut on the other hand, she had not intended or planned for this to happen, she was being exploited by others who imposed themselves on her and she was fearful.aposapos Baker who has since moved to Bolton was initially charged with blackmail, kidnap,  imprisonment and causing grievous bodily harm with intent but her not guilty pleas to those charges were accepted. Five men are due to be sentenced later over the kidnap.  In mitigation for Bakeraposs defence, Ian Metcalfe called for his client to be jailed saying it would provide an opportunity for her to get herself clean. He added: aposaposIf this house was not available then they would have found another house in which someone  would have been preyed upon. She was targeted by others because of her obvious weaknesses and vulnerability and she was exploited by very dangerous iniduals. aposaposShe should have said aposnoapos but that was never going to be accepted and she was not up to the task to say aposnoapos in any event. She has never prospered and has had a most wretched le.aposapos  Sentencing Judge Elizabeth Nicholls said: aposaposThis group of men used your house to imprison Kane Aitchison, torture him and subject him to degrading violent treatment. It is right to note that you were to a degree as much a victim as he was. The people who came to your address undoubtedly used you as they knew you would put up no resistance when they arrived at your door. aposaposIt is not asyou invited them to your house but you simply had little choice in the matter. You had no part in the violence but of course, you were present when you heard some of the violence being inflicted. I hope when you are released you will be drug-free and that this time in custody will give you the support you need to turn your le around.aposapos Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON HospitalsCourt caseCrown courtCrimePrescriptionsTorture" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: new highway code rules mean
story: New Highway Code rules mean you could face a fine for using a mobile even as a passengerCar passengers could face being handed a hefty fine of £they are caught using a phone in a car according to new Highway Code rules which came into force on FridayNew Highway Code restrictions have come into force Image: Getty ImagesByGraeme Murray:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |comments You could face a fine for using a mobile evenyouaposre a passenger under new Highway Code rules.Drivers who even touch a phone face could be hit with a £ penalty after tough new rules came into effect on Friday. If a person is supervising a driver who is learning, they could be hit with £, fine - as well as a massive six points on their licence. Current rules under the Highway Code make texting or calling while driving illegal. But new rules brought in on Friday means many grey areas have been tightened, making more actions illegal. In , it was ruled in the High Court that an offence was committed when a mobile was used for an interactive communication .  This included calling or texting, but now using a phone for any purpose, is seen as reckless and dangerous. Now drivers can no longer touch their device, take photos or videos, access playlists or use other apps while they drive. Phone use at traffic lights or in motorway queues will also be seen as illegal under new Highway Code rules. Anyone using a device while driving faces a £ fixed fine plus six points added to their driving licence. Motorists are, however, permitted to use their phones to pay at a drive-thru restaurant or a road or bridge toll. The Department of Transport : There will be an exemption to the new law for drivers making a contactless payment using their mobile phone while stationary to ensure the law keeps pace with technology.This exemption will cover, for example, places like a drive-through restaurant or a road toll, and will only apply when payment is being made with a card reader. It will not allow motorists to make general online payments while driving. Hands-free devices can be used when driving including taking calls or using a satnav, but onlyit is secured in something which holds it. title: overlooked dog spends 750 days
story: Overlooked dog spends  days at RSPCA after being rescued from neglectful homeFour-year-old Layla has become one of the RSPCAs longest stay dogs despite her  lovely and playful personality - she is still searching for a new place to call homeLayla is still searching for a homeByPaige FreshwaterContent Editor:,  Mar |commentsThe RSPCA has issued a desperate plea for help rehoming a dog who has spent  days in their care - making her one of the longest stay residents with the charity. Four-year-old Layla was taken in by the RSPCA Sheffield Animal Centre in January  after she was rescued from a house in West Yorkshire. She was found in a neglected state with all her bones visibly protruding from her body. But now she is a picture of health, the RSPCA team want to secure her a new home as they feel her nervous nature may have put people off adopting her in the past. They are confident her lovely and playful personality will win over experienced owners and someone will be able to give her a home.to our TeamDogs newsletter for your weekly dose of dog news, pictures and stories. Hayley Crooks, animal lead at the branch said: Layla is our favourite girl. She is so lovely and likes to spend time with people she trusts and her fun-loving side also likes getting up to some mischief at times! She can be incredibly nervous around new people but with careful introductions and lots of tasty treats she will make friends. She loves to have lots of fun games to play and enjoys her time outside adventuring. During her time with us Layla has spent time in foster homes, where she learnt how to enjoy le in the home. However she may need slow introductions to the new home and general le outside kennels.  Layla was taken in by the branch following an RSPCA investigation. Inspector Kris Walker was sent to an address in Knottingley, West Yorkshire, following a report by a member of the public who was concerned about the welfare of the dog. He found Layla was emaciated with her spine, pelvis and hips clearly prominent and her owner agreed to sign her over into RSPCA care so could receive emergency veterinary treatment. A veterinary examination found Layla had a body score of one out of nine, with one being the lowest, which is an emaciated state. The vet estimated she had been suffering for between six and eight weeks.Kris said: I am delighted to see how Layla has been transformed in the care of RSPCA Sheffield Animal Centre.Due to her circumstances staff at the branch do have some requirements for her new home, but we just know that there is a loving owner out there for her. Layla’s new home would have to be with experienced owners who would be able to spend lots of time with her. She would need someone who is home a lot of the time to help settle her in. As Layla can be quite worried and anxious around other dogs -especially when in her space. -Ii would also have to be a home with no other pets. She walks well on the lead but she has been muzzle trained as she is nervous of other dogs when they come close to her. Hayley added: She really is so lovely and sweet and we all love her dearly and know her forever home is out there.If you can offer Layla her perfect forever home please email us over a completed application to customerservices@rspcasheffield.org.Do you have a dog story to share  Email paige.freshwater@reachplc. news uk-news school-run-mum-admits-using-"Insulate Britain: Woman appears to drive car into protesterByAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Mar |comments A mum has admitted to using her Range Rover to try and move an Insulate Britain protester who was blocking the road while she was on the school run.Sherrilyn Speid, , appeared at Southend Magistratesapos Court today and pleaded guilty to a charge of dangerous driving.The mum from Essex had been at the wheel of her black Range Rover Sport when she came across an Insulate Britain protest in Grays at about .am last October. The scene was caught on camera by a passer-by and heavily-bleeped footage was shown in court. Prosecutor Ashley Petchey said three protesters were sitting across the road and queues of traffic had built up behind them.  Speid got out of her vehicle and remonstrated with the demonstrators, the court heard. A woman is seen telling the protesters they must move out of the way now and my son needs to go to school and I need to go to work. She also says: My son is  and he needs to go to school. Of the dangerous driving count, Mr Petchey said: It is not an excessive speed as the driver was using the brakes quite heavily. This is done on two occasions.  The Range Rover stops very close to the female protester. Mr Petchey said the dangerous driving meant that injury could have been caused. He said: Clearly this was an incident where there was a risk, evenno injury was caused. An assault charge against Speid, in which it was alleged that protester Bethany Mogie had been beaten, was dismissed after the prosecution said it would produce no evidence.The prosecution said it would ask for £ in costs and a pre-sentence report was ordered. Peter Hoche, chairman of the bench, unconditionally bailed Speid to next appear at Basildon Magistratesapos Court on May  for sentencing. He also banned Speid from driving by issuing her with an interim driving disqualication. At the height of the Insulate Britain road-blocking protests, Speid attempted to move the activists with her Range Rover.  “What they’re doing is wrong, she said afterwards. They’re not peaceful, they’re obstructive and they’re rude, she continued. I’m upset I lost my temper and maybe I could’ve gone about it in a dferent way but I will always stand up for what I believe in — that people should be entitled to live their normal lives. She said at the time that she was standing up for other mums who needed to take their children to school in the mornings. Insulate Britain has demanded that the government invest money in making Britainaposs homes less leaky and cold, in a bid to save energy and therefore protect the environment. news uk-news student-who-thought-spotty-rash-"Student suffers from spotty red rash on her legsByNia PriceKit Roberts:,  Mar |comments A student who thought a horrying red spotty rash that covered her lower body was caused by apos partying too much apos was stunned when doctors said it was actually apostriggered by her contraceptive pillapos. Ella Holley claims she started taking the Cerazette mini pill back in October but three days later dashed to Gloucester Royal Hospital AE as strange apostiny red spotsapos began appearing all over her legs.The -year-old said she experienced a series of aposflare-upsapos where a painful red rash extended from her feet up to her waist and slightly on her arms, having seven flare ups in under three weeks which left marks even after the rash had faded. The hotel receptionist claims when it was at its worst it caused joint pain akin to a apossprained ankleapos and her skin had the excruciating sensation of being aposset alightapos each time it was touched. She eventually saw a specialist in January and claims she was told sheaposd experienced Henoch-Schonlein purpura , a disorder where small blood vessels become inflamed, as a side effect of taking the contraceptive pill. Have you suffered a medical drama  Email webnews@mirror to tell your story  With her scarring now faded, Ella has vowed to never go near the mini pill again and is keen to raise awareness of the potential side effects that women can experience when putting contraception into their bodies. Ella, of Gloucester, Gloucestershire, said: When it first appeared I didnapost have a clue what it was. I was worried because with being at university I was like aposis it the pill thataposs doing this  Is it alcohol  Is it being out in the cold after a night out maybe apos I was just concerned about what it was. I was living the standard university student le which I would say can be quite unhealthy at times and is what I thought was causing this.  I was living with the lack of routine, poor choice of diet and the alcohol too, but no more than any other students I knew, so I didnapost understand why this only happened to me. On top of that, the next day Iaposd eat the most rubbish food. I was living a very unhealthy lestyle at the time. I thought maybe my body was trying to react to that and tell me that it had had enough or I needed to stop doing that. If something goes wrong Iaposll automatically blame myself and thought aposoh God, is it something Iaposm doing aposThe singleton said she experienced her first aposflare upapos on October th - just three days after first taking the pill - and her parents were concerned she may have measles. She rushed to AE, and after spending  hours there Ella was told by doctors that they werenapost sure what it was and referred her to a rheumatologist. She stopped taking her pill two days later. Ella said: It flared up and would get to its worst and then gradually start going down.I couldnapost really put my finger on it because it would calm down and obviously Iaposd stopped taking the pill at this point and then Iaposd go on a night out or to work for the day and it would come back in little spots. When it was at its worst I had joint pain in both ankles. It felt like Iaposd almost sprained my ankle or something. It felt like my skin had been set alight every time something touched it, especially in the shower and when I went to bed. I remember being sat on my sofa and my friend knocked my leg and it was horrically painful.Ella said her flare-ups seemed to happen after sheaposd been on her feet. Apart from her initial one the worst she experienced was after her nieceaposs wedding at the end of October, and prior to that day the markings on her skin had started to subside considerably. Ella said: It was very sore. It was a case of cold showers because the hot water felt like burning, it felt like someone had a lighter to my skin. During the first two or three days I only showered maybe once or twice because it was so painful. Something  I found very painful was when I was in bed and had my duvet rubbing against it. I had to stay so still until I fell asleep because there was no tossing or turning around.Luckily I live with a house full of girls and I used to walk around the house in pretty much a hoodie and a pair of pants because I wouldnapost want anything touching or rubbing against it. It was awful, I hated it. Trying to find things to wear for events and stuff was just, it brought me to tears multiple times. I was gutted. It was just embarrassing because when the girls were dresses to go out, I had to wear a pair of jeans that would cover down past my shoes. Luckily the university student hasnapost had any new spots appear since around th December.She claims she visited the rheumatologist on the th January and was told she had Henoch-Schonlein purpura , and that it shouldnapost reappear but thereaposs a possibility it could. Ella posted her experience online to raise awareness given prior to this year sheaposd never heard of HSP or of women having any similar reaction as a result of taking contraception. Ella said: The doctor said that it was HSP, which was a result of taking the pill. It was nice to know that it was something rather than one of those stories where thereaposs never really an answer to it and you just kind of have to live with it. So in a way I was relieved. Iaposve not taken any contraception since. Thereaposs no way Iaposd take the mini pill again, I just donapost think itaposs worth the risk, personally for me. Because thataposs happened to me, I in no way want to discourage anyone  trying it, but my bodyaposs had that reaction to it and I know thereaposs a chance it could potentially come back and I wouldnapost want to do that again - spend the next four months of my le covering up. People will always make their own final decisions but I wanted to share my experience so that people are aware, which hopefully makes them feel both more comfortable and confident in the choices they make, as I believe this is not spoken of enough. Iaposm not saying at all that this is going to happen to everyone but this is my experience, take from it or leave from it what you please. A spokesperson for Organon said: Nothing is more important to Organon than the safety of our products and the people who use them. We are confident in the research that supported the approval of Cerazetteand its use in clinical practice in multiple countries around the world since its approvals. As with all of our products, we continually monitor the safety of Cerazette. title: tiny one eyed puppy found
story: Tiny one-eyed puppy found in rotting rubbish in desperate need of new homeEight-month-old Masea was discovered in a horrible state alongside her litter siblings but after being cared for by Blind Dog Rescue UK, she is now searching for a new place to call homeMasea was abandoned in rubbish with her litter siblingsByPaige FreshwaterContent Editor:,  Mar |commentsShe was dumped in rubbish at just weeks old - and is now desperately searching for somebody to give her a second chance at le. Poor Masea, now eight-months-old, was discovered in rotting waste in a horrible state alongside her litter siblings. The poor pooch was suffering from flystrike, a painful condition caused by flies laying their eggs on another animal. These hatch into maggots, which eat the flesh of their aposhostsapos.Sadly for Mesea, this caused her to lose sight in one of her eyes, meaning she is now having to adjust to le as a partially-sighted dog. But this isnapost her only health concern as Mesea is also deaf in one ear after having to have her ear canal removed following a complication. to our TeamDogs newsletter for your weekly dose of dog news, pictures and stories.Despite living in a private shelter in Moldova, she is currently up for adoption with Blind Dog Rescue UK and is ready to board a flight when a family is found. A spokeswoman at Blind Dog Rescue UK said: Masea is eight-months-old as of March  and weighs .kg. Masea was found as a newborn along with her siblings. Masea is a typical youngster who is friendly with dogs, with people and with children. She is a little more lively than her brothers and sister. She is impatient, and can be noisier than the others. She would love a home with a garden and can live with another dog for company Our adoption donation is £. This includes travel to the UK, their vaccinations, pet passport, microchip and all preparation for travel. They also come with  weeks free insurance.Blind Dog Rescue UK works to rehome blind and partially sighted dogs who have been subjected to the “worst of humanity yet still have an astonishing capacity to adapt, love and become perfect ambassadors for blind dogs everywhere”. Many of the dogs in their care have been victims of abuse, neglect, disease or trauma - and struggle to survive in shelters. A Blind Dog Rescue UK statement reads: “It is incredibly dficult for sighted dogs to survive anyof time in these shelters let alone blind or partially sighted dogs. “We need to get to these dogs quickly and secure their immediate release and treatment.  “These dogs may have been deliberately blinded, involved in road traffic accidents or long term sufferers of painful conditions such as glaucoma.“They need veterinary care and to be given the safety and comfort of a foster home in which to start healing. “Here they are given love and affection and a warm bed - possibly the first they will have experienced in their letimes. At this point, we are able to start assessing and promoting these wonderful dogs for forever homes.To adopt Masea, or any other animals in Blind Dog Rescue UKaposs care, contact their team via their website www.bdruk.org.Do you have a story to sell  Email paige.freshwater@reachplc.Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON TeamDogsDogsAnimals" data-immediate"data-immediate"Calling all dog lovers!to TeamDogs for your weekly dose of dog news, pictures and stories.Invalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: toddler turned newborn baby again
story: Toddler turned into newborn baby again as illness causes her brain to swellLexie Forsyths parents have said the rare mystery condition has left their daughter like a newborn baby again unable to talk, walk, or feed herselfLexie Forsyth and her mum Emilia Blanaru Image: Michael TraillByClaire ElliotKit Roberts:,  Mar |comments The parents of a four-year-old girl have said that a mystery brain condition has left her like a newborn baby again. Lexie Forsyth from Inverness is like any other toddler and loves to play with her friends, but seven months ago she began developing a mystery illness. The condition has caused her brain to swell, which has left her unable to talk, walk, or to feed herself, the Daily Record Daily Record reports.Her parents Emilia Blanaru and Mark Forsyth, who have separated, have even described the devastating illness as rendering their daughter a new born baby again.Nonetheless, tough Lexie has fought back against the condition, following months of therapy and a staggering  days in hospital. She has astounded medics and is now able to make the -minute walk to nursery – ­something her parents feared might never happen. Doctors are unable to say whether she will make a full recovery and she still uses a wheelchair for long distances. But Emilia said: “Like a baby, she had to learn everything from the beginning again. We had to lt her up, she couldn’t walk, or sit, or feed herself.We had to put her in nappies again. “But she never gave up. We just take it little by little each day.” Lexie, who lives with her mum and brother Daniel, two, in Inverness, has been crowned Brave Child of the Year at a Highland Heroes awards ceremony. Her proud gran, Alison Canavan, nominated her after watching Lexie fight every obstacle with her infectious smile.  Emilia said: “She is a happy girl and she is always smiling.” The family’s ordeal began when Lexie fell ill last summer, and started vomiting and having seizures. Doctors initially put her ­symptoms down to a viral infection but her ­condition worsened and she fell into a coma for seven days. After two months, they confirmed Lexie had been hit by a rare ­inflammation of the brain called acute disseminated encephalomyelitis . Get the stories you want straight to your inbox.toone of the Mirroraposs newslettersMark, from Thurso, Caithness, said: “The way they explained it, her body was fighting the virus and accidentally attacked her brain.” Lexie had months of speech therapy and physiotherapy. She was able to walk unaided after four months and is excited to be back at nursery. But doctors are unable to say what the future holds. Emilia added: “We just have to wait and see. One thing – she is stubborn, she never gives up.” Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON HospitalsNewborn babyTherapyParentingPeople" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: two bedroom london home market
story: Two-bedroom London home on the market for just £, but is definitely not a bargainThe two-bedroom property in Catford, South London, is in need of urgent repair and refurbishment but could be up for grabs for £,The flat has just hit the market with a starting price of £, Image: rightmoveBySamantha Mordi:,  Mar |commentsSavvy house-hunters may think they are in for a bargain when they spot this two-bedroom London property, but they are in for a shock. The flat based in south-east London, has a courtyard garden, double-glazing and permit parking, but bargain buyers will be amazed when they see in the inside.The home is less than appealing on the inside and only has  years left on lease.The £, flat on Morena Street in Catford, is in need of urgent work and repair. In one bedroom, pictures show a half-packed suitcase which appears to be lying open on a bed, while a dress has been hung from a curtain pole. The second bedroom is filled with junk, including chairs, a clothes horse and a bucket. The hob in the kitchen is coated with grime and filth, with a kettle and dirty pans stacked on top. A rubbish bag still hangs from a hook, The Sun reports.The bathroom is also grim, with stains on the floor around the toilet and sink. Bags of rubbish have been fly-tipped in the garden. Auctioneers at Town and Country Property say the home will be sold off on April .  They said: The accommodation comprises of an entrance hall, lounge, kitchen, two bedrooms and family bathroom with a rear courtyard. It requires full refurbishment throughout. For those prepared to put in the work and pay to increase theof the lease, the flat could one day make a sweet home. Itaposs moments from Catford shopping centre, as well as restaurants, bars and supermarkets.  Itaposs also a short walk to two big train stations, as well as two pretty parks. This comes after a three-bedroom home is up for auction for just £,. But images showing the home’s state of disrepair attracted attention for all the wrong reasons.The home in Llandudno, Wales, which is currently expected to sell for just £,, is in need of some major TLC, North Wales Live reports. Each room is incredibly run-down, with piles of rubbish strewn all over the place. One room shows a pack of Stella Artois on the bedside cabinet which,youaposre lucky, could end up coming with the auctioned property.
