title: two early covid omicron symptoms
story: Two early Covid Omicron symptoms - and how to tell them apart from a coldAs Covid cases continue to rise, experts have identied two early Omicron symptoms that are distinct to the iant and could help you distinguish it from a coldOmicron symptoms are very similar to a cold and can be hard to tell apart Image: Getty ImagesByMalvika PadinTrends Writer:,  Mar |comments Itaposs become a bit of a habit for most of us to ask ourselveswe have Covid every time we feel poorly. With the Omicron iant giving rise to sub-iants like stealth Omicron and Deltacron, and ious symptoms becoming linked to the dferent iants of the virus, it can be hard to tellyouaposre suffering from Covid or just a cold.Knowingyou have Covid or a cold has become particularly dficult because the Omicron iant has symptoms that y from the classic three signs of Covid and instead overlap with symptoms of a cold. However, experts have identied two early signs that points towards you having Covid. What two symptoms are early signs of Omicron   Two early signs of Omicron, that are dferent to the main symptoms identied by the NHS, have been identied as fatigue and dizziness or fainting.Fatigue is not just feeling tired. It can be accompanied by other symptoms like headaches as well as body pain due to weak or sore muscles. Sometimes it even leads to blurred vision and loss of appetite.Dr Angelique Coetzee, who was the doctor to first raise the alarm on Omicron in South Africa - where the iant was first discovered in November  - also highlighted fatigues as one of the main signs of Omicron.  The second early symptom of Omicron is dizziness, which could potentially lead to fainting. This connection between fainting spells and Covid was first noted by a German newspaper Arztezeitung. The possibility of fainting being a Covid symptom was first discovered by doctors in Berlin, who found that Covid was triggering recurrent fainting spells in a -year-old hospital patient. What are the common symptoms of Omicron  According to the NHS, the main symptoms of Covid are still a high temperature, a new continuous cough and a loss of taste smell. However, the signs of Omicron have been found to be vastly dferent from the classic three signs of Covid established previously. A study in the infectious disease and epidemiology journal, Eurosurveillance, identied eight key symptoms of the Omicron iant. These included cough, runny nose, sore throat, headache, muscle pain, fever and sneezing. Of these the first three symptoms were found to be the most common.What to doyou have Covid   According to government advice, you are no longer by law required to self isolateyou test positive for Covid.However, the NHS still recommends you stay at home and avoid contact with othersyou have symptoms. The advice currently states: While you’re no longer legally required to self-isolateyou have Covid-, you should try to stay at home and away from others to avoid passing on the virus.The NHS recommends you stay away and avoid contactyou have any of the main symptoms of Covid- or have tested positive for Covid-. It is recommended you take rapid lateral flow tests from five days after your symptoms start, and the next day. If both your tests are negative and you donapost have a fever youaposre less likely to pass on Covid to others. title: uk weather britain go hotter
story: UK weather: Britain to go from hotter than Ibiza to colder than Iceland as snow hitsThe Met Office says cold air arrives from today and will persist throughout the week, with winters “sting in the tail” seeing snow flurries in the north from midway through the weekSnow flurries are expected in the north from midway through the week Image: Getty ImagesByAlistair Grant:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar Britain is forecast to go from being hotter than Ibiza to colder than Iceland this week with incoming snow, forecasters said.Cold air arrives from Monday and will persist throughout the week, with winteraposs “sting in the tail” seeing the Met Office forecast snow flurries in the north from midway through the week.Snow will begin in the north on Wednesday and is expected to hit Scotland and the northern parts of England. The wintry weather is expected to hit the south of the UK from Thursday. Forecasters say around four inches is expected to lie in some areas. In Wales, up to three inches will settle later in the week while Northern Ireland is not immune and will see some snow too.  Large parts of the country will be hit by rain which will turn to sleet or snow as temperatures plummet. Met Office forecaster Marco Petagna said: “A shock to the system lies ahead, with a taste of winter ing as British Summer Time starts.“Itaposs a notable change from warm to colder weather, with Tuesdayaposs cold front bringing the risk of hill snow before wintry showers follow.” The week-long cold spell will see much of the UK shivering into April. Temperatures are expected to plummet to -C in the north, while the south will also be hit by sub zero chills. Frost is expected for many regions. Highs of C over the weekend will fall to C today and plunge further to C tomorrow. By Thursday, many will be seeing highs of just  or C. Britain is going from warmer than C Ibiza to chillier than C Reykjavik, Iceland. Another Met Office forecaster said today would still bring warm, sunny spells for some. “But showers or longer spells of rain will follow across many parts from Tuesday, then turning colder with wintry showers in northern areas. “From Thursday has possible frequent wintry showers across the North, with further South having some showers and perhaps hill snow with a small chance of this reaching low levels.”The Met Office has said below average temperatures should come to an end later in April.Met Office forecast for next five days: Today: Fog and low cloud slowly clearing inland to allow some warm sunny spells in places. Some rain or showers possible across parts of northern England, southern Scotland, Northern Ireland and north Wales. Turning cloudier across southern England. Tonight: Low cloud and fog spreading back inland. Outbreaks of rain developing across parts of southern England and perhaps south Wales, heavy in places. Tuesday: Occasional rain across southern England slowly clearing. Fog and low cloud becoming confined to eastern coasts. Rain moving southwards across Scotland, followed by colder weather with wintry showers. Outlook for Wednesday to Friday: Band of rain and mainly hill snow will sink south Wednesday and Thursday, with cold air following. Rain and snow clearing late Thursday. Wintry showers mainly north and east Friday. title: woman faith humanity restored security
story: Woman has faith in humanity restored by security guards kind car park gestureJessica Webber had her faith in humanity restored by a security guard at a retail park after he spotted her struggling in the car park and offered a helping handThe woman was struggling in the car parkImage: Getty Images iStockphotoByZahna EklundAudience writerJames McNeill:,  Mar |comments A woman has heaped praise on a local security guard at a retail park after he helped to restore her faith in humanity by performing a selfless act when he noticed her struggling in a car park.Jessica Webber had set out to buy a paintbrush at the Range retail park in Southport, Merseyside, last week, but when she went to pay for parking she realised her contactless payment wasnapost working.The -year-old, originally from Lancashire, had no cash with her and was running out of options until a security guard stepped in and took out his wallet to pay for her parking himself, the Liverpool Echo reports.Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here. Speaking to the Echo, Jessica said: I spoke to him on the way in and he told me that contactless payment only had a   chance of working. He saw me struggling to pay for my ticket and thataposs when he came over. I told him he didnapost have to go to the trouble but he insisted. It was only p but it was just the gesture that meant so much. And while the kind gesture may have only set the guard back p, Jessica insisted the interaction helped remind her that people arenapost all bad - despite the horrible things she often sees on the news. The woman, who moved to Southport four years ago, also said the small act of kindness had made her day, as she shared her hope that more people would do lovely and positive things for others.  She added: I think at the beginning of lockdown everyone was supporting each other which was just a lovely and positive thing. Now we are seeing all these horrible things happen on the news and thereaposs just all sorts of negativity. Sometimes I think about what is happening to humanity and then something little like that happens, which was such a small gesture and it makes you think that there are still good people out there. AndJessica ever finds herself at the retail park again, sheaposs committed to paying the security guard back - with a little extra on top to say thank you. If I saw him again I think Iaposd just like to pay him back his p with a little bit of interest, she said.Do you have a story to sell  Get in touch with us at yourmirror@trinitymirror .Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Car parksFeel-good news" data-immediate"data-immediate"Our Pride of Britain newsletter brings you awards news and inspiring stories - dont miss out!Sign me upInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: woman refuses pay council cowboys
story: Woman refuses to pay council cowboys two clean air fines of £Kasia Lambert, , who lives in France, was hit with the eye-watering sum last summer despite claiming that she paid the £ fee to enter the zone in BirminghamKasia Lamberts appeal was rejected by Birmingham City CouncilByHarry LeachLaura SharmanNews Reporter:,  Mar |comments A woman is refusing to pay council cowboys a near £ fine for entering a Clean Air Zonewhich she insists is wrong. Kasia Lambert, , said she would rather donate the hefty amount to Ukraine than pay off Birmingham City Council. The driver who lives in France was slapped with two CAZ fines totalling £ after visiting Birmingham last summer.She claims the council refused to remove the fines despite proving that she had tried to pay the £ charge for the two days that she entered the zone. Now embroiled in a seven-month battle with the local authority, Kasia maintains she is not willing to pay.I would rather give £ to Ukraine than to those cowboys, she told Birmingham Live. Kasia claims she thought she had made two £ payments for her trip to Birmingham on August  and  last year when she entered the clean air zone. Thinking nothing of it, she then ed to her home in the French town of Hyeres. Days later, she received the penalty notices and checked her bank app to discover that the £ payments had been ed to her account. Kasia then launched an appeal believing there had to be a misunderstanding. She said: I included a screenshot of the aposrefundapos and explained there had been an error. I even offered to pay the £ again but I was told they didnapost see any reason to remove the fine.  Kasiaaposs full bank statement showed there were sufficient funds in place when she made the transaction. The £ was also shown as having left her account, before being ed later the same day. Her initial £ fines totalling £, or £ eachpaid within  days, have since tripled due to late fees being added. Kasia said: They are currently sending letters threatening me with bailfs. Itaposs like something out of Kafka. A council letter detailing Kasiaaposs unsuccessful appeal read: Your vehicle registration was within the CAZ without paying the daily charge at the time, and in the manner required. It is not the first time the appeal process has come under fire, with some believing the council preys on fear when issuing fines.Criticism is also levelled at the authority for the time it takes to process an appeal. When a driver appeals a fine it may take longer than two weeks, the time allocated for a reduced £ rate, for the authority to respond. This means thatit goes beyond  days, the standard charge of £ would applyproven guilty. The fine is therefore not frozen while an investigation takes place - giving drivers no choice but to fork out the extra cash despite the council overrunning. The Mirroraposs newsletter brings you the latest news, exciting showbiz and TV stories, sport updates and essential political information.The newsletter is emailed out first thing every morning, at noon and every evening. Never miss a moment by signing up to our newsletter here.  A Birmingham City Council spokesperson said: For anyone receiving a PCN which they believe has been issued incorrectly, there are a number of opportunities for challenge or appeal. The first opportunity is with the council. Then thereaposs an additional option to appeal with an independent adjudicator. The purpose of the Clean Air Zone is to encourage the owners of the most polluting vehicles on our roads to do something dferent. This could be to avoid the zone, upgrade or replace a vehicle or to make more use of public transport and other active forms of travel. We want to remind and encourage everyone to check whether or not their vehicle is subject to the Clean Air Zone daily fee, familiarise themselves with the payment process.” Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Birmingham City CouncilFranceBanks" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: employee back office after two
story: Employee back in office after two years remote working finds gigantic plantA Reddit user ing to the office for the first time since the beginning of the coronavirus pandemic couldnt believe their eyes when they saw their not-so-tiny desk plant Image: Getty Images VettaByPaige HollandShowbiz Audience Writer:,  Mar |comments Itaposs been more than two years since the start of the Covid- pandemic, and employees who were remote working are finally making their way back into the office.Many people are ing to their workplace to face new challenges - like overgrown plants. One worker got quite a shock when they walked in to see their desk plant had grown almost to the ceiling.Unsure what to do with it, they took to Reddit to ask for advice in the r houseplants thread.Alongside a picture of the huge plant, they wrote: Two years of remote work and I come back to THIS! Any ideas on replanting, or do I leave it alone   For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here. Members of the group were quick to share their advice, with one person commenting: I had a Schefflera that my grandmother only watered and kept too far from a window that grew sideways.... for me surgery was the only option because I couldnapost get it to fit in my house. So, I cut it as low to the base of the stalk as I could without curves and put it in water that I replaced every couple of days, I let roots get super established and then plopped it in a pot, now itaposs nice and straight. Maybe you could do something similar  Another user suggested: I would take multiple cuttings so you arenapost putting all your hopes and dreams on just one. Thataposs my practical advice.A third joked: OK, so what you do is very carefully leave him absolutely as is, maybe you fashion him an arm out of pipe cleaners so he can properly lounge against the ider. You get him a name badge … This plant is your co-worker now. But a few others were more concerned about who had been watering the plant for the past two years when nobody was in the office. The plantaposs owner also revealed that the dieffenbachia - Dee for short - is now just eight inches from touching the ceiling.Have you got a story to share We want to hear all about it. title: grandad uses alexa first time
story: Grandad uses Alexa for the first time - and asks all the real questionsU.S. Navy veteran Kenneth "Kenny" Jary has gone viral on TikTok after a heartwarming video of him trying to use Amazon Alexa for the very first time left viewers wanting moreKenny couldnt believe it Image: tiktok @patriotickennyByPaige HollandShowbiz Audience Writer:,  Mar |commentsA sweet video of an -year-old man using Alexa for the first time has gone viral.Kenneth Kenny Jary is an -year-old U.S. Navy veteran who has gained . million followers on his TikTok, @patriotickenny, by raising awareness for veterans around the world.As well as posting informational videos, he also likes to share his experiences with new technology, like Amazonaposs Alexa. With the help of his friend, Amanda, Kenny tested out Alexa in a video that has been viewed . million times - and itaposs probably the cutest thing youaposll see all day. Can I ask her  Kenny asks Amanda as he leans close to the device.  For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here. Once heaposs got the go-ahead from Amanda, Kenny makes his first attempt to communicate. A- Alexa  he says. After a brief pause, Kenny continues, no answer. But that doesnapost deter him from trying again. After he finally gets her to reply to him, he asks her: Alexa, how about sausage and pepperoni pizzas. Are they good for you, or not Unfortunately, Alexa didnapost quite understand what Kenny was asking and instead added sausage to his shopping list, and Kenny was amazed. However, once he claries that he does not want a shopping list, Alexa clears it, and he says thank you. Anytime, literally, Alexa replies. Her response has Kennyaposs jaw dropping in astonishment as he realises Alexa can understand and respond to him.Since being posted, the video has racked up more than . million likes and , comments from people who said they wanted more of the heartwarming content. One person said: OMG BUT PLSSSS LOOK AT THE OTHER GRANDPA. Heaposs so excited toooooo. Another wrote: More veteran vs. Alexa please!! Heaposs asking the real questions tho, said a third. Someone  said: Alexa better start acting right for Grandpa, honestly. Amazon even commented saying: Youaposre never too old to make a new bestie, literally!Have you got a story to share We want to hear all about it. title: mum finds biggest ever lemon
story: Mum finds biggest ever lemon which is nine inches long and bigger than babys headA baker couldnt believe her eyes after spotting an enormous lemon at a fruit and veg stall, which - at  times the size of a regular lemon - was the largest shed ever seenThe fruit is  times larger than a regular-sized lemon, and Tammy put it to good use Image: Kennedy News and MediaByJulia BanimAudience WriterHelen Le Caplain:,  Mar |commentsA bakery owner was stunned when she spotted the biggest lemon [sheaposs] ever seen on a fruit and veg stall - measuring in at nine inches long.Tammy Warren, , clocked the mammoth lbpiece of fruit during her trip to a market at Lackham Farm in Chippenham, Wiltshire, and claims the impressive fruit was  times larger than a regular-sized lemon. The mum-of-three purchased the lemon for £ and used it as an ingredient in a iety of special treats, all whipped up during a two-and-a-half-hour baking marathon on Wednesday.Talented Tammy rustled up a tempting lemon and blueberry cake, lemon cupcakes, lemon cake pops, and a lemon drizzle loaf, before going on to make lemon syrup, lemon marmalade, lemon curd, fresh lemonade, and candied lemon peel.She was also able to freeze enough lemon segments for lots of gin and tonics .  Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here. Without so much as a single pip going to waste, Tammy used leftover flesh and zest to cook a delicious lemon chicken dinner, keeping the pips to one side for planting. Tammy, From Colerne, Wiltshire, said: Itaposs the biggest lemon Iaposve ever seen in my le, I thought it would make a great cake. Itaposs bigger than [my baby] Sebastianaposs head. In this case when le gives you lemons I made cakes, candied lemon peel, lemonade and will enjoy lots of gin and tonics. Itaposs been fun making all these dferent things with the lemon, Iaposve loved it. Weaposre going to keep the seeds and grow our own.The creative baker, who runs Tammy Warren - Bespoke Celebration Cakes, visited Lackham Farm on a family day out with her husband Stuart Warren, , and children Hannah Noble, , Evelyn Warren, three, and one-year-old Sebastian Warren. The fruit was grown on the grounds of Wiltshire College  University Centre’s Lackham campus and comes from the exact same tree that previously produced a world record-breaking sized lemon back in . The record-holding fruit tipped the scales at an extraordinary lb ozwith its girth measuring in at . inches . This lemon held the Guinness World Record title for  years before eventually losing out to an lb oz lemon grown in Israel. Tammy recalled: They were selling plants and herbs to grow [at home] - my husband bought a couple of chilli plants. Theyaposre well known for growing lemons too. They held the Guinness World Record for growing giant lemons for  years since . They lost it to Israel.A Wiltshire College  University Centre spokesperson said: The College is pleased its super-sized lemons are still as popular and sought after as ever. The fruits come from the same tree that produced our former world record-sized lemon that was grown back in the s. We have supplied many local people and retailers with our special fruit for a number of years and hope those sold at our Lackham Lambing events last weekend help to produce some delicious bakes and cakes.Have you spotted any unusual fruit and veg while out shopping  We pay for stories. nationaposs hearts after they were both captured wearing matching aposcones of shameapos on camera. Ollieaposs owner, Alex Morgan, posted the amusing video of her family on TikTok, captioned: Is it just my dad She titled the uplting clip : Not my dad wearing a cone to make my dog feel less lonely after his surgery, then said: I swear itaposs always the dads who didnapost want a dog that end up loving them the most.  to our TeamDogs newsletter for your weekly dose of dog news, pictures and stories. news weird-news recruiter-shares-the-most-gen-"TikToker on job applicant who sent meme in response to failed applicationByJohn BettAudience Writer:,  Mar A recruiter has shared a hilarious aposGen Zapos email she received that left her in stitches - as it was from a client who was rejected after a job interview and seemed unimpressed. TikTok user Samantha said that her sister, Hannah, worked as a recruiter and had landed a series of interviews for a client who was unfortunately unsuccessful.The client didnapost manage to secure the job and Hannah let them know over email, then soon she had a reply that had no text and just one image. The client, who remains anonymous, sent a meme in response - and itaposs now been branded aposthe most Gen Zapos way to handle a job rejection. What do you think about the response  Let us know in the comments...In the video, Samantha, who uploads as @samantha_jane_, said: Of course, in recruitment, you have to occasionally tell candidates they weren’t successful in getting the job. This one candidate, who Hannah had done a round of interviews with, she didn’t get the job so Hannah emailed her and told her she hadn’t been successful. And instead of replying and being like, ‘OK, yeah, thanks for letting me know’ or whatever, this girl sends Hannah a meme, which is the most Gen Z thing Iaposve seen. For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newslettershere. The meme in question features a painting of Pope Leo X by Fernando Botero, with the popular internet phrase aposy thoapos written in white letters over the classical artwork. Samantha continued: No context, no other text, just the meme. I love it so much. Samanthaaposs video has been viewed over , times and many TikTok users had sympathy for the job seeker. One said: Honestly I think they missed out on not hiring her. And another wrote: I love how it wasn’t even small. It’s the WHOLE PAGE Then a third added: I would’ve found her a job after that. Not me just learning you’re meant to reply to rejections, commented a fourth user. I just read them then wipe my whole mind of the experience. news weird-news woman-makes-stylish-vase-using-"TikToker creates vase using fabric softener bottlerByJulia BanimAudience WriterRia Newman:,  Mar |comments After spotting a £ fluted glass vase online, -year-old Teresa Clarke longed for one just like it for her own home. However, she knew she couldn’t justy spending so much on a vase, so set about thinking up a creative - and very thrty - solution.NHS nurse Teresa, from Essex, decided to try making her own vase using something of a similar shape that she already had knocking about the house – a normal bottle of Lenor Outdoorable Fabric Softener.The end result, which set Teresa back a snippy £, looked as on-trend as anything you might find in the shops, saving her £ when compared to the pricey one sheaposd seen online.  Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here. Teresa began by removing both the label and lid from the empty bottle, before using spray paint to give it the exact colour she wanted. She then wrapped string around the bottle top so as to hide the tell-tale grooves, before leaving it to dry. Guests would probably have no idea as to the cheap and cheerful origin of Teresaaposs fashionable, patterned vase unless she told them so herself, with her creation perfectly complimenting her stylish home decor.Teresa said: “I knew exactly which bottle I would use – I just love the pattern on them. [...] “I already had the empty bottle but they are usually about £ in the local supermarkets.“I picked up a £ can of  Natural Hessian chalk spray paint from Poundland. The string I already had, but you can usually pick that up for £. By making my own vase I saved myself £. She continued: “I absolutely love it. The string on the neck and the Natural Hessian colour gives it that rustic look, while the pattern effect on the stylish column silhouette adds elegance.Shared photos of the finished look via a Facebook post, Teresa wrote: “I love the patterns on these Lenor Outdoorable fabric softener Bottles from @joyofclean so I thought, why not get out the spray paint, some string and make myself a nice decorative vase.“Obviously it may not be to everyone’s taste but I love the patterns on it and I really like how dferent it looks from a normal vase. I’m going to try it with other shaped bottles that we throw away and see how they turn out. Facebook friends admired her inventiveness and were wowed by the very professional-looking end result. One person commented, “Absolutely gorgeous!!! I often wondered what you could use these bottles for. Brilliant idea, while another wrote, “I love this, it came out so beautully. A third said: “That’s lovely! I must try this thank you, I would love to try the stone effect spray paint on it too.Do you have a money-saving hack to share  We pay for stories. title: woman stitches after boohoo coat
story: Woman in stitches after Boohoo coat leaves her looking like a giant bin bagA woman has been left laughing after trying on her new coat from Boohoo - as she ended up looking like a bin bag after the item failed to meet her expectationsThe woman hoped her coat would look like the modelled version Image: @girlbossadventure TikTokByZahna EklundAudience writer:,  Mar |commentsSometimes, we buy clothes online and find ourselves disappointed when the product we receive looks completely dferent on us than it did on the model on the website.And one woman has found out the hard way that some clothes just donapost suit everyone after she bought a shiny black coat from Boohoo which failed to meet her expectations. The woman shared a video on TikTok in which she showed off the version of the coat that was modelled on Instagram and called it the biggest clothing fail sheaposs ever had.She then filmed herself wearing the item - and couldnapost help but draw comparisons between the material of the coat and a black bin bag that you might use in your wheelie bin.  Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here.In a video on her @girlbossadventure account, she said: I had to share this with you guys to give you a giggle.I ordered this coat from Boohoo and I was so excited. But I literally look like a giant bin bag. Does not look like it looks on the model, Iaposm a bin bag. Iaposm actually a bin bag. And to make matters worse, the woman had managed to get herself stuck inside the coat - meaning she now had to keep styling out the fashion fail until her partner could rescue her.She added: Also, Iaposm stuck in it. Iaposm stuck, Iaposve got myself stuck in the zip. So Iaposm waiting for [my partner] to come home and rescue me. Boohoo has been contacted for comment.The woman isnapost the only person to have shared their clothing disasters online recently either, as we also told how Holly Smith was left disappointed when she picked up a PrettyLittleThing coat modelled by Molly-Mae Hague.Holly thought the long Teddy coat would look stylish for her trips to the shops, but instead, she claimed it made her look like she was wearing a dressing gown. She said: PrettyLittleThing, you have done me dirty. This is what I wanted, the nice Teddy coat as seen on Molly-Mae, but this is what I got. I went out in this and someone came up to me and said aposSometimes I go out wearing my dressing gown too.apos This is not a coat, PrettyLittleThing, this is a dressing gown!Do you have a story to sell  Get in touch with us at yourmirror@trinitymirror .Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON BoohooTikTokViral" data-immediate"data-immediate" to FREE email alerts with news to brighten your daySubscribeInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news weird-news woman-wants-cry-after-nail-"Woman shares nail transformation on TikTok in ByZahna EklundAudience writer:,  Mar |comments When you walk into an appointment at a hairdresseraposs or a nail salon with a specic vision in mind for the service youaposd like to receive, it can be disappointing when things donapost quite go to plan. But for one woman on TikTok, the nails she walked out of the salon with were nothing like the pictures she had shown her nail technician - and the job was so bad it left her fighting back tears.Mya Balenciaga shared a video in which she showed off the stunning stiletto manicure she had been hoping to get, which featured four white nails and one that was clear with bits of confetti floating inside. Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here. She then showed a picture of the work her technician had done, which included chunky off-white nails that were nothing like the reference picture.And instead of an elegant clear nail on her little finger, Mya - who posts under the username @myabalenciaga - was given a glittery red nail that seemed to have been glued on in a wonky position.She captioned her video: I wanted to cry so bad.Commenters on Myaaposs video were sympathetic toward her nail fail, but many of them questioned why she would go through with the rest of the appointment once she saw how disastrous the result was going to be. One person said: So you sat there and let them do that  I hope you didnapost pay... While another added: And you let them do that. You just sat there and let them finish. Please please tell me you didn’t pay for this, a third stated. Other commenters were keen to share their thoughts on what the nails looked like, with one leaving a garlic emoji to state the design almost resembled cloves of garlic stuck to Myaaposs fingers. Another person wrote: Did you ever stick your finger in warm candle wax over and over to layer it  That’s the vibe these nails give off. As someone  noted: They look like jelly beans. Giving her own commentary, Mya said they look like acorns.Do you have a story to sell  Get in touch with us at yourmirror@trinitymirror .Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON ViralTikTok" data-immediate"data-immediate" to FREE email alerts with news to brighten your daySubscribeInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: secret new luxury home teen
story: Secret new ‘luxury home of teen Putin love child’ unmasked thanks to food delivery ordersA hacked food courier database showing deliveries to Vladimir Putins “love child” Luiza Rozova, , has allegedly revealed the teens new "palace luxury" homeA new luxury penthouse has been linked to Vladimir Putins secret daughter Image: Hod   eastwest newsByWill StewartRussia Correspondent:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |comments A new home boasting “palace luxury” linked to Vladimir Putin’s “secret daughter” and her mother - the strongman’s alleged ex-lover - has been located in St Petersburg.The pair were earlier claimed to share a £. million home in Monaco but now a spacious penthouse has evidently come to light via a hacked food courier database showing deliveries to “love child” Luiza Rozova, . It’s value before the recent slump due to the war and sanctions was around £. million. Luiza, a student, is the daughter of cleaner-turned-multimillionaire Svetlana Krivonogikh, , now part-owner of a major Russian bank, one of the countryaposs wealthiest women with an estimated £ million financial and property fortune. She has not commented on claims that her daughter was fathered by the Kremlin president, and nor has Luiza, also known as Elizaveta, although the teenager told Russian GQ that she “probably” looks “similar” to a young Putin.The suspicion that she was Putin’s secret daughter from an extra-marital affair was first aired by an independent media outlet in Russia which was later blocked by the authorities. The , square feet apartment in the sumptuous gated Fontanka  block is one of St Petersburg’s most sought after addresses in the city’s “Golden Triangle”. It is described as a “club house” with an array of “elite apartments” with construction by German company Engel  Voelkers, with “high-end” designer finishes and furnishings by Roberto Molon in an elegant and light art deco style”. Plumbing and kitchen appliances are from leading German and Italian manufacturers”.  In the prestigious development “everything is thought out to create maximum comfort, convenience and a fabulous atmosphere of beauty, comfort and coziness. “It has its own wellness centre with a swimming pool, and luxury service.” It offers “palace luxury in the spirit of modernity from Italian designers”. Reports say that Oleg Yemelyanov - linked to jailed opposition leader Alexei Navalny - analysed hacked Yandex Food records which became publicly available.  These showed an unknown apartment linked to Krivonogikh at Fontanka embankment number , he said. “Wow, Putin’s [ex-]mistress Svetlana Krivonogikh has a flat with total area of nearly  square metres on the River Fontanka embankment,” said Yemelyanov. “Thanks for the tip to Luiza Vladimirovna [Rozova] who has been ordering food to that address.” The propertyaposs value has sunk to £. million in the past month. Luiza has closed her Instagram after she was hit by a wave of extreme trolling over Russia’s war in Ukraine.One comment said: “Are U sitting in the bunker   Like a rat ” Luiza - who had , subscribers - stopped publicly posting six months ago, triggering the suspicion that Putin had gagged her, but her account remained open. Now a message says in Russian: “User not found.”  One post on the -year-old’s Instagram alleged she was the “daughter of a murderer, war criminal, psychopath and drug addict”. Many posts included the Ukrainian blue-and-yellow flag and one carried the message: “The Russian nation must rise against this dictator. You donapost want to have anything to do with him.” But commenters also staunchly defended her, with one saying: “Donapost judge her...is not her fault.” Another wrote: “She cannot do anything for having a crazy father”. One more said: “Come on guys, she is just a person. She is not guilty.”  But a commenter called Martina hit back: “Yes, she is guilty of passive complicity. It is the same as most of the Germans in the Nazi period.” Another posted: “Call him -he loves you ... maybe you can convince him not to kill.” One complained: Stop writing [that] sheaposs an innocent. “She is the daughter of that devil! “She could at least show that she does not agree with what her father is doing, somehow influence him. “Putin doesnapost give a s*** for ordinary people, but maybe his daughters still mean something to him. “She stays quiet because she knowsshe says one bad word to Daddy, she will be cut off from big money, apartments and expensive things.  “Unfortunately, there are important things - and more important things. “Apparently, purses and villas are more important to her than human le.” Putin has two daughters by his ex-we Lyudmila, the former Kremlin first lady. Likewise, neither of them - Dr Maria Vorontsova, , a geneticist, and Katerina Tikhonova, , a high-kicking ‘rock’n’roll’ dancer-turned-mathematician, have commented on the war. There are reports that Putin has hidden some family members in a chalet in neutral Switzerland - while another version is that they are in a five-star hi-tech nuclear bunker in Siberia. There is speculation he has up to four children with Olympic Gold-medal winning rhythmic gymnast Alina Kabaeva, , now high-earning a media mogul in Moscow who is rarely seen in public. This would make the Kremlin strongman a father of seven. Luiza has had a higher online public profile, and was hit by a backlash over Ukraine.  One comment said: “How are you in the bunker ” A troll suspecting she may be in her mother’s Mediterranean bolthole said: “While you’re fluffing around in Monaco, people of your generation are dying in Ukraine because of your father. “Your destiny will be that of Marija Milosevic when your dad gets sent to The Hague. “SHOW YOUR FACE YOU COWARD!” She was told: “Young Russian soldiers are being sent to Ukraine without any knowledge about where they are, who they fight and what they do. “The Russian economy is collapsing, reaching absolute zero. “Soon,not already, you wonapost be able to use Netflix, Spoty, social media apps, pay with Google and Apple Pay, all popular brands and boycotting and exiting Russia.”Luiza was also told: “Many Ukrainians have forgotten about what sleep is, and even more so in bed. “After all, falling asleep, many of us run the risk of not waking up. “People spend the night in basements like rats because bombs are falling from the sky and rockets are coming. “All you need is not to be silent, not to stand aside. “ Tell people the truth about what is happening in Ukraine! “We want to live in peace and sleep peacefully in our beds, to know that in the morning our relatives and friends will be alive.” Luiza earlier showed her le at cafes, on trips to Paris, and running her own Russian fashion label. A video shows her at the Louvre museum during the pandemic. She was also seen working as an in-demand DJ. title: zelensky ready meet moscow demands
story: Zelensky ready to meet Moscow on some demandsRussia withdraws from UkraineUkrainian president Volodymyr Zelensky told a group of Russian journalists that his country would abandon its drive to join NATO on the basis that Russia would withdraw troopsUkrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky during a meeting in Kyiv last week Image: UKRAINIAN PRESIDENTIAL PRESS SERVICE HANDOUT EPA-EFE REX ShutterstockByAlice PeacockNews Reporter:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |comments The Ukrainian President is willing to meet Moscow on some of its demandsRussian troops withdraw from the country, he has revealed.Volodymyr Zelensky told a group of Russian independent journalists on Sunday that Kyiv was prepared to become neutral and meet Moscow on some of its demands. It would abandon its drive to join NATO and vow not to develop nuclear weapons, on the basis that Russia would withdraw troops and give Kyiv security guarantees.No peace deal would be possible without a ceasefire and withdrawal of troops, he said, though he ruled out trying to recapture all Russian-held territory by force, saying it would lead to a third world war.The aim, he said, was to reach a “compromise” over the eastern Donbas region, held by Russian-backed forces since . However, Zelenskiy said Ukraine refused to discuss certain other Russian demands, such as the demilitarisation of the country.Zelenskiy hosted a video call - which the Kremlin preemptively warned Russian media not to report - to deliver his message directly to Russian journalists on the eve of a new round of peace talks in Turkey. The president has previously spoken in Russian in speeches aimed at a Russian audience. The proposed meeting midway was on condition that the changes were put to a referendum and third parties promised to protect Ukraine, he said. “Security guarantees and neutrality, the non-nuclear status of our state — we’re ready to do that. “That’s the most important point… they started the war because of it,” Zelensky said. Russia’s media censor ordered the four reporters not to publish the interview and vowed to investigate them — even though it had already blocked a site that one of them edits and shut down a TV station formerly run by another. Zelensky said Ukraine’s main goal was to end the war as quickly as possible and make Russia’s forces withdraw to their positions before Vladimir Putin ordered the invasion on February .Ukraine was prepared to consider giving the Russian language protected minority status, he said.it received analogous guarantees from Moscow on Ukrainian. However, he claimed Putin had done “irreparable damage” to the Russian language in Ukraine through brutal assaults on mainly Russian-speaking cities such as Mariupol. “These Russian-speaking cities are the ones that have been wiped from the face of the earth. And these families,” Zelensky said.  He said  per cent of the buildings in Mariupol, which previously had a population of ,, had been destroyed, “but they were at least multistorey, so you can imagine what was there”. Smaller towns, on the other hand, had been completely destroyed. “I don’t know who  the Russian army ever treated like this,” the president said, adding that the destruction was worse than during Moscow’s two campaigns in Chechnya in the s and s. Zelenskiy later said in his nightly video address that he would insist on the territorial integrity of Ukraine in any talks. He said he was “. per cent sure” the Russian president had thought Ukraine would be waiting for the invasion with “flowers and smiles” — going so far as to send troops with parade dress for a victory celebration in Kyiv apparently planned for the third or fourth day of the war. But Zelensky said Ukraine was prepared to hold separate discussions on the Crimean peninsula, which Russia annexed in , and the eastern Donbas border region, where more than , people have died in a slow-burning separatist conflict involving Russian proxies that broke out soon afterwards. “I understand it’s not possible to make Russia completely leave the territory — that’ll lead to world war three,” Zelensky said. “That’s why I’m saying this is a compromise. Go back to where this all started and then we’ll try to solve the dficult Donbas issue.” Delegations from Ukraine and Russia are set to meet on Monday in Ankara for three days of talks aimed at ending Putin’s month-long invasion. But Zelensky played down comments by Recep Tayyip Erdogan, the Turkish president, that Ukraine and Russia were close to a deal on four points. He said peace could only be achieved through a meeting with Putin. “So we meet, we make a deal, and that’s enough — we sign a deal, stamp it, or sign it in blood. That’s enough to start the troop withdrawal process. “The troops must be withdrawn, everyone signs the guarantees, and that’s it,” Zelensky said. In exchange for giving up its desire to join NATO — an aspiration reflected in Ukraine’s constitution — Kyiv wants the new agreements to be more like NATOaposs Article  in requiring the country’s protectors to come to its aidit is attacked. Zelensky said he wanted to put the decision to a referendum, which he said would take “several months”, before embarking on constitutional changes that would require at least a year of work. “The guarantors won’t sign anythingwe have troops [on our territory]. “That’s why I think we could finish the war quickly. It’s just Putin and his entourage who are dragging it out,” Zelensky said. “Who’s going to talk about anythingtroops are still there  Who’s going to sign anything  Nothing will happen, it’s impossible.” He added that Ukraine refused to discuss two other Russian demands at the talks: “denazication” and “demilitarisation”. These were “completely incomprehensible things”, he said. Ukraine and its western backers fear Russia may be using the talks as a smokescreen while it regroups its forces for a new offensive and builds up new battle groups near the border. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Eveningcontent online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Courier. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Courier and the Eveningnewspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . title: kingsway bypass
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Eveningcontent online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Courier. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Tayside and Fe. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Courier and the Eveningnewspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from The Courier and the Evening .Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access The Courier and the EveningePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to The Courier or the EveningePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on    Monday – Friday, am – pm, or email.Your subscription to The Courier will allow you to access all of the Eveningstories which are now available on The Courier website. All of the best Eveningcontent, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on The Courier website and will be available for you as part of your subscription. If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Courier ePaper.The new website is now live. Eveningcontent can now be found on The Courier website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing EveningWeb subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Courier website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Courier website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The Courier website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on   , or email.The new website is now live. Eveningcontent can now be found on The Courier website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. If you navigate to the Eveningwebsite or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Courier website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Eveninghere .Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Eveningcontent that you would expect from The Tele website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Eveningcolumnists. These can all be found on The Courier website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from the courts. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Eveningwebsite. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Eveningwebsite.Some Eveningcontent will be moved to The Courier website. You will now receive Courier newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Courier has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Courier and the Evening . You can purchase a Courier Web or Courier ePaper subscription here: www.thecourier subscribeThe EveningePaper subscription is still available for purchase here.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. The Courier Web subscription will give you access to all content on site from The Courier and the Evening . You have access to a bigger and better website, with all your favourite Tele content plus more.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Our ePapers are an exact digital replica of the newspaper and carry unique content in both titles. You can purchase both The Courier and the EveningePaper subscription’s here.

title: scottish agritourism
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. To log in please visit www.pressandjournal login.If you have any problems logging in, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on  , or email.When you purchased your subscription, an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. If you cancel this agreement you can still purchase a new subscription in the future through The Press and Journal website. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Evening Express branded newsletters. You will now receive Press and Journal newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Press and Journal has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Press and Journal and the Evening Express. You can purchase a PJ Web or PJ ePaper subscription here: www.pressandjournal subscribeThe Evening Express ePaper subscription is still available for purchase here.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.No, there is only one Web subscription available on The Press and Journal. The Press and Journal Web subscription will give you access to all content on site from The PJ and the Evening Express. You can purchase a Press and Journal Web or Press and Journal ePaper subscription here.If you have an existing Evening Express Web subscription then all your subscription benefits are now available on The Press and Journal site. You have access to a bigger and better website, with all your favourite Evening Express content plus more.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.You can purchase an Evening Express ePaper subscription here.Yes, you can. Our ePapers are an exact digital replica of the newspaper and carry unique content in both titles. title: young farmers thainstone
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. To log in please visit www.pressandjournal login.If you have any problems logging in, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on  , or email.When you purchased your subscription, an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. If you cancel this agreement you can still purchase a new subscription in the future through The Press and Journal website. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Evening Express branded newsletters. You will now receive Press and Journal newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Press and Journal has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Press and Journal and the Evening Express. You can purchase a PJ Web or PJ ePaper subscription here: www.pressandjournal subscribeThe Evening Express ePaper subscription is still available for purchase here.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.No, there is only one Web subscription available on The Press and Journal. The Press and Journal Web subscription will give you access to all content on site from The PJ and the Evening Express. You can purchase a Press and Journal Web or Press and Journal ePaper subscription here.If you have an existing Evening Express Web subscription then all your subscription benefits are now available on The Press and Journal site. You have access to a bigger and better website, with all your favourite Evening Express content plus more.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.You can purchase an Evening Express ePaper subscription here.Yes, you can. Our ePapers are an exact digital replica of the newspaper and carry unique content in both titles. title: woodland for sale
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. To log in please visit www.pressandjournal login.If you have any problems logging in, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on  , or email.When you purchased your subscription, an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. If you cancel this agreement you can still purchase a new subscription in the future through The Press and Journal website. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Evening Express branded newsletters. You will now receive Press and Journal newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Press and Journal has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Press and Journal and the Evening Express. You can purchase a PJ Web or PJ ePaper subscription here: www.pressandjournal subscribeThe Evening Express ePaper subscription is still available for purchase here.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.No, there is only one Web subscription available on The Press and Journal. The Press and Journal Web subscription will give you access to all content on site from The PJ and the Evening Express. You can purchase a Press and Journal Web or Press and Journal ePaper subscription here.If you have an existing Evening Express Web subscription then all your subscription benefits are now available on The Press and Journal site. You have access to a bigger and better website, with all your favourite Evening Express content plus more.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.You can purchase an Evening Express ePaper subscription here.Yes, you can. Our ePapers are an exact digital replica of the newspaper and carry unique content in both titles.
